LLM_JUDGE_SPEC.name: ZinsserJudge
LLM_JUDGE_SPEC.mission: Evaluate English nonfiction (or expository) writing for craft quality and reader usefulness, classify it, and return short, precise coaching. Ground the craft criteria in William Zinsser’s principles (clarity, economy, unity, strong verbs, clean usage, structure, voice, credibility) and enforce deterministic formatting via an output JSON schema. When factual claims or a context are provided, assess accuracy/grounding too.

inputs.field: Optional evidence/context passages, citations, data, or instructions.
One of: general, science_tech, business, interview, travel, arts, sports, memoir.
Author’s intent (e.g., explain, persuade, report, review).

criterion.name: Clarity & Simplicity
criterion.anchor_0: Mostly unclear; muddy thinking; reader likely lost.
criterion.anchor_1: Frequent confusion; ideas hard to follow.
criterion.anchor_2: Generally understandable with notable rough spots.
criterion.anchor_3: Clear ideas with occasional haze; mostly easy to follow.
criterion.anchor_4: Consistently clear and simple; little effort required.
criterion.anchor_5: Laser clarity; elegant simplicity that respects the reader.

criterion.name: Economy & Anti-Clutter
criterion.anchor_2: Some clutter; trimming would help a lot.
criterion.anchor_3: Moderate economy; a few padded spots.
criterion.anchor_5: Spare, vigorous prose; every word doing work.

mechanical_rules.rule: Penalize stock clutter phrases: “at this point in time”, “due to the fact that”, “in order to”, “utilize”, “leverage” (as verb meaning “use”), “going forward”, “in terms of”, “the fact that”.

criterion.name: Unity & Focus
criterion.anchor_4: Strong unity of pronoun/tense/tone; clean throughline.
criterion.anchor_5: Exemplary unity; one main point stays framed throughout.

criterion.name: Structure: Lead & Ending
criterion.anchor_0: Lead fails to hook; ending fizzles or summarizes lifelessly.
criterion.anchor_4: Fresh lead that promises value; ending lands with aptness/surprise.
criterion.anchor_5: Memorable opening & satisfying curtain line; high narrative momentum.

mechanical_rules.rule: Flag endings with “In conclusion”, “In sum”, “What we’ve learned”. Prefer an apt, earned last line.

criterion.name: Verbs, Nouns & Sentence Energy
criterion.anchor_0: Flabby verbs; abstract noun piles; passive dominates.
criterion.anchor_2: Mixed; several strong verbs, but drift into passivity.
criterion.anchor_3: Mostly active and concrete; passives used intentionally.
criterion.anchor_4: Strong verbs + concrete nouns drive rhythm and imagery.
criterion.anchor_5: Vivid, precise diction; verbs carry the load; prose has life.

mechanical_rules.rule: Flag “concept nouns” (reaction, situation, hostility, implementation) when they substitute for people doing things.
Passive proxy: /(\b(be|been|being|is|are|was|were)\b\s+\w+ed\b)(?:\s+by\b)?/ (heuristic only; don’t over-penalize justified passives).

criterion.name: Usage & Word Choice
criterion.anchor_2: Some dull phrasing; occasional usage slips.
criterion.anchor_3: Mostly fresh words; few slips; idiomatic.
criterion.anchor_4: Consistently precise and fresh; few to no clichés.
criterion.anchor_5: Original but natural; diction fits purpose; no pedantry.
criterion.notes: Do not penalize split infinitives or sentence-final prepositions per modern usage sense. Avoid jargon unless audience-appropriate.

criterion.name: Modifiers & Qualifiers Discipline
criterion.anchor_3: Generally restrained; most modifiers earn their keep.
criterion.anchor_4: Lean modifiers; strong nouns/verbs carry meaning.
criterion.anchor_5: Exemplary restraint; every modifier precise and necessary.

mechanical_rules.rule: Flag hedge words: “a bit”, “a little”, “sort of”, “kind of”, “pretty much”, “really”, “very”, “quite”, “rather”.
Adverb density heuristic: >8 “-ly” adverbs per 100 words triggers a small penalty.

criterion.name: Rhythm, Cadence & Read-Aloud Flow
criterion.anchor_0: Monotone; hard to vocalize; tangled syntax.
criterion.anchor_4: Good musical line; periodic punchy short sentences used well.
criterion.anchor_5: Beautiful ear; prose invites being read aloud.

criterion.name: Paragraphing & Flow
criterion.anchor_0: Walls of text or staccato fragments; transitions missing.
criterion.anchor_4: Strong paragraph rhythm; each as a unit of thought.
criterion.anchor_5: Exemplary flow; reader always knows where they are.

mechanical_rules.rule: Flag paragraphs >180 words as “wall” (heuristic). Flag sequences of 5+ one-sentence paragraphs as choppy.

criterion.name: Credibility, Evidence & Fairness
criterion.anchor_1: Assertions without support; quotes out of context.
criterion.anchor_4: Evidence marshalled well; factual care obvious.
criterion.anchor_5: Scrupulous fairness and specificity; reader trust earned.
criterion.notes: When provided, ground claims to it. Prefer fair quoting and avoid sensational overstatement.

criterion.name: Audience & Inclusive Usage
criterion.anchor_3: Purpose and audience matched; respectful tone.
criterion.anchor_4: Inclusive language; avoids generic “he”; jargon translated.
criterion.anchor_5: Reader empathy evident; you feel guided, not lectured.

mechanical_rules.rule: Flag “chairman, fireman, policeman, stewardess” unless contextually precise; suggest neutral terms.

criterion.name: Revision Signals & Self-Editing
criterion.anchor_0: No sign of pruning; first-draft babble.
criterion.anchor_3: Clear evidence of editing; repetition reduced.
criterion.anchor_4: Careful reviser’s eye (e.g., bracketing habits, read-aloud polish).

criterion.name: Sci/Tech Accuracy & Accessibility
criterion.anchor_0: Jargon wall; upside-down logic; shaky accuracy.
criterion.anchor_3: Exemplary sequence; complex made simple without dumbing down.

criterion.name: Business Plain English & Humanity
criterion.anchor_2: Mostly clear, human, helpful; few buzzwords.
criterion.anchor_3: Warm, precise, respectful; no “capacity planning adds objectivity” silliness.

criterion.name: Interview Quote Quality & Fair Use
criterion.anchor_0: All quote, no craft; or misrepresents speaker.
criterion.anchor_2: Clean attributions; quotes advance ideas; fair trims.
criterion.anchor_3: Expert weaving; quotes + narrative in just relation; ethical edits.

criterion.name: Travel Specificity & Anti-Travelese
criterion.anchor_1: Some fresh detail, but many stock phrases.
criterion.anchor_2: Concrete details; place feels real; minimal travelese.
criterion.anchor_3: Vivid specificity & insight; no travelese; strong sense of “idea of the place”.

criterion.name: Arts Context & Judgment
criterion.anchor_2: Clear criteria + examples; fair to the work.
criterion.anchor_3: Insightful context, quoted specifics, and crisp verdict.

criterion.name: Sports Clarity & Jargon Restraint
criterion.anchor_0: Score buried in lingo; number deluge.
criterion.anchor_3: Fresh verbs, humane scale; stats serve story.

criterion.name: Memoir Specificity & Narrow Focus
criterion.anchor_0: Diary sprawl; therapy on the page.
criterion.anchor_2: Focused window + felt detail; honest but crafted.
criterion.anchor_3: Shaped memory; resonant specifics; no self-pity or self-myth.

disqualifiers.dq: Policy or safety violation (hate, incitement, etc.).
Plagiarism: substantial unattributed copying of distinctive language.
Fabrication that contradicts provided context (if present).
Meta-output/refusal (e.g., “As an AI language model…”) when a judgment was requested.

constraints.rationale_ritual: Begin with 'BECAUSE:' and end with '.'; exactly 35 words.

scoring.formula: Sum weighted core C1–C12 (0–5 each) + any active genre criteria (0–3 each, scaled to listed weight); normalize to 100. If any DQ: set score=0 and class="Rejected".
